title: Trump Says Global Trade Is Unfair. Does He Have a Point? - (Published 13 hour(s), 27 minute(s) ago)
content: President Trump says that countries have been ripping off the United States for decades. There is some truth to that argument — but also a lot of hypocrisy.
resumen:
President Trump has accused America’s trading partners of undermining the United States for decades, saying they have engaged in unfair trade practices to steal the country’s wealth and enrich their own economies. He has set his sights not only on adversaries like China, but also traditional allies like Canada and Europe. Mr. Trump has promised to correct this situation on Wednesday, when he announces expansive tariffs on foreign products.

The United States has long been more open to trade than many countries globally. Some countries do have tough trade barriers to U.S. exports, or economic policies that distort global markets — particularly China.

Mr. Trump’s claims include a heavy dose of exaggeration, as well as hypocrisy. Mr. Trump has singled out high tariff rates that countries charge on certain U.S. exports including Europe’s tax on cars and India’s levy on motorcycles. But the United States also has high tariff rates that it charges on certain imports, such as a 25 percent fee on light trucks. Mr. Trump has lumped in friendly allies like Canada, which have some limits to U.S. exports outside a few sectors, with nations like China, which have extensive trade barriers.

The trade measures that Mr. Trump has introduced so far have more than tripled the estimated dollar value of tariffs that importers must pay to bring products into the United States compared with last year. In his first term, Mr. Trump’s collective tariff actions on foreign metals, China and other products ended up doubling U.S. tariffs.

Mr. Trump is referring to his plan to impose reciprocal tariffs as “Liberation Day.”

William Reinsch, a senior adviser at the Center for Strategic and International Studies, called the president’s claims about trade “a huge exaggeration.”

Data from the World Trade Organization showed the United States had a trade-weighted average tariff rate of 2.2 percent in 2023, compared with 2.7 percent for the European Union, 1.9 percent in Japan, 3.4 percent for Canada, 3 percent for China and 1.7 percent for Switzerland. India’s trade-weighted average tariff rate is 12 percent, while Mexico’s is 3.9 percent and Vietnam’s is 5.1 percent.

The United States levies individual tariff rates on about 13,000 foreign products. The U.S. trades with almost 200 countries.

India charges a 50 percent tariff on imported motorcycles, a 60 percent tariff on automobiles and a 150 percent tariff on alcoholic beverages. Canada’s dairy system charges a high tariff after a certain volume of imports is reached, a system known as a tariff-rate quota. Goods imported from the United States above quota levels “are subject to prohibitively high tariffs,” like 245 percent for cheese and 298 percent for butter. The European Union charges a 50 percent tariff on American dairy and Japan charges a 700 percent tariff on American rice.

The United States charges 350 percent tariffs on tobacco from many countries, 260 percent tariffs on Irish butter substitutes and 197 percent tariffs on Chinese stainless steel kitchenware. The United States also has relatively high tariffs on peanuts, apparel, footwear and sugar.

China has wielded huge subsidies and other economic practices that give its industries a competitive advantage. Beijing’s approach has fueled the growth of a $1 trillion-plus trade surplus. The Office of the United States Trade Representative said this week that China had used industrial planning and other policies to target sectors like robotics, aerospace, new energy vehicles and biopharmaceuticals for “domination.”

Mr. Trump has placed an additional 25 percent tariff on many products from Canada, but only an additional 20 percent tariff on goods from China.

title: 'Will do everything to avoid trade war': How world leaders reacted to Donald Trump’s reciprocal tariffs - (Published 9 hour(s), 36 minute(s) ago)
content: Italy's conservative Premier Giorgia Meloni described the new 20 per cent tariffs against the European Union as “wrong,” saying they benefit neither side.
resumen:
World leaders reacted to Donald Trump’s reciprocal tariffs. President Donald Trump announced new tariffs on nearly all US trading partners — a 34 per cent tax on imports from China and 20 per cent on the European Union, among others.

The British government said the United States remains the UK's “closest ally.” Business Secretary Jonathan Reynolds said the UK hoped to strike a trade deal to “mitigate the impact” of the 10% tariffs on British goods announced by Trump. Reynolds said, "Nobody wants a trade war and our intention remains to secure a deal," and added that "But nothing is off the table and the government will do everything necessary to defend the UK's national interest.”.

Italy's conservative Premier Giorgia Meloni described the new 20 per cent tariffs against the European Union as “wrong,” saying they benefit neither side. Meloni said, “We will do everything we can to work towards an agreement with the United States, with the aim of avoiding a trade war that would inevitably weaken the West in favour of other global players”.

Brazil's government said it was considering taking the case to the World Trade Organization. Brazil's Congress unanimously passed a reciprocity bill to allow its government to retaliate against any country or trade bloc that imposes tariffs on Brazilian goods.

Australian Prime Minister Anthony Albanese said the US tariffs imposed on his country were totally unwarranted, but Australia will not retaliate. Albanese said, “President Trump referred to reciprocal tariffs. A reciprocal tariff would be zero, not 10 per cent”.

New Zealand trade minister Todd McClay said New Zealand was “a very low tariff regime” and the correct figure was below the 10 per cent baseline rate applied by the US to all countries. McClay said, “We won't be looking to retaliate. That would put up prices on New Zealand consumers and it would be inflationary”.

Mexico President Claudia Sheinbaum said she would wait to take action on Thursday when it was clear how Trump's announcement would affect Mexico.

Canada had imposed retaliatory tariffs in response to the 25 per cent tariffs that Trump tied to the trafficking of fentanyl. The European Union, in response to the steel and aluminum tariffs, imposed taxes on 26 billion euros' worth (USD 28 billion) of US goods, including bourbon, prompting Trump to threaten a 200 per cent tariff on European alcohol.

Heck, who serves as Chair of Washington’s Legislative Committee on Economic Development and International Relations, has led trade missions to Canada, Mexico, Taiwan, and the United Kingdom. Vicki Fabre, executive vice president for the Washington State Auto Dealers Association, raised concerns that increased tariffs could make it more difficult for consumers to afford new and used vehicles. Estimates range from $2,000 to over $10,000 per vehicle.

title: ‘Liberation Day’: A timeline of Donald Trump’s trade war with Canada - (Published 13 hour(s), 34 minute(s) ago)
content: For over a year before the November 2024 presidential election, Donald Trump had been signalling plans to impose across-the-board tariffs if he won the United States presidency. Trump was elected on ...
resumen:
Donald Trump had been signalling plans to impose across-the-board tariffs if he won the United States presidency for over a year before the November 2024 presidential election.

Trump was elected on Nov. 5, and it’s been a roller-coaster ever since for Canadian leaders and businesses. He has threatened, enacted, modified and delayed multiple rounds of tariffs only to announce additional protectionist trade policies are to come.

The duties are widely seen as inflationary in the U.S., and with Canada’s retaliatory tariffs enacted in response, inflation is also a risk north of the border. Meanwhile, tariffs are likely to weigh on both economies and could even cause a recession.

The Canadian dollar began sliding in the fall of last year and has been hovering around 70 cents US in recent months. Stock markets in Canada and the U.S. have whipsawed with every new piece of tariff news and traditional haven investments like gold have soared in value amid the uncertainty.

Here’s a timeline of the key dates in Trump’s tariff journey after he was elected president:

*   **Nov. 25, 2024:** Trump pledges to impose a 25 per cent tariff on all Canadian and Mexican imports, saying they would come into force on inauguration day, Jan. 20. He says in a post on Truth Social, a social media site he owns, that the tariffs would remain until both countries stop drugs, particularly fentanyl, and people from illegally crossing American borders.
*   **Dec. 11:** After Canadian premiers met with then-Prime Minister Justin Trudeau, they confirm the country is preparing retaliatory tariffs in response to Trump’s threat. Securing an exemption or lower levies on energy exports is among the priorities.
*   **Jan. 20, 2025:** On his inauguration day, Trump says tariffs will likely come on Feb. 1 rather than taking immediate effect. He also signs an executive order to enact an “America First Trade Policy,” calling for his trade and commerce officials to report back to him by April 1 on a sweeping review of U.S. trade policy and relationships. The date does not come with a default imposition of any tariffs, but does direct Trump’s administration to begin examining the Canada-U.S.-Mexico free-trade agreement, which Trump signed in 2018, ahead of a planned 2026 review.
*   **Feb. 1:** Trump signs an order on Feb. 1 — a Saturday — imposing blanket tariffs of 25 per cent on virtually all goods entering the U.S. from Canada and Mexico, and a reduced 10 per cent tariff on energy, set to take effect on Feb. 4. Trump’s Feb. 1 order also imposes 10 per cent tariffs on goods entering the U.S. from China. Prime Minister Justin Trudeau outlines Canada’s planned retaliation strategy, including immediate counter-tariffs that would take effect the same day U.S. tariffs kick in. Over the weekend, Canadian provinces start pulling American alcohol from liquor-store shelves at provincially owned distributors.
*   **Feb. 3:** Trump pauses the implementation of tariffs on Canadian goods for one month after Ottawa pledges action to secure the border. He does the same for Mexico.
*   **Feb. 10:** Trump signs a plan to institute 25 per cent tariffs on all steel and aluminum entering the U.S. starting March 12, ending previous exemptions for Canada. Trump previously imposed tariffs on the metals in 2018 but later exempted Canada and Mexico.
*   **Feb. 11:** Trump says the steel and aluminum tariffs would stack on top of other levies, including the paused 25 per cent tariffs on all Canadian goods other than energy.
*   **Feb. 14:** Trump had previously threatened to levy tariffs on imported automobiles coming into the U.S. He says on Feb. 14 that tariffs on imported automobiles could come “around April 2,” adding the following week that the levies would be “in the neighbourhood of 25 per cent.” Around the same time, he floated imposing similar tariffs on pharmaceuticals and semiconductors, but has yet to provide a timeline for those.
*   **Feb. 27:** In a Truth Social post, Trump says that April 2 would mark the start of what he terms “reciprocal” tariffs, which would apply to goods coming in from countries that have tariffs or other barriers on U.S. goods. These would be on top of other tariffs and would match the rates charged by other countries, including subsidies and value-added taxes. He had signed a memorandum on Feb. 13 directing his trade czar to examine what he perceives as unfair trade practices from other nations.
*   **March 4:** Trump’s tariffs on Canadian and Mexican goods go ahead after the month-long pause. There had been hopes that the border security measures Canada took could stave off the tariffs, but on March 3, Trump confirmed they would go ahead, which they did. Prime Minister Justin Trudeau announced broad retaliatory tariffs on U.S. goods including food, alcohol, furniture, paper and more.
*   **March 5:** Trump pledges a one-month exemption for vehicles traded under the Canada-U.S.-Mexico Agreement, also known as CUSMA. White House Press Secretary Karoline Leavitt says during a briefing that the move comes after the Big Three automakers — Stellantis, Ford and General Motors — asked for an exemption.
*   **March 6:** Finance Minister Dominic LeBlanc says Ottawa will suspend its second wave of retaliatory tariffs after Trump signed an executive order to pause some new duties on Canada and Mexico and reduce potash levies to 10 per cent. Trump’s order links the tariff relief to maintaining the flow of automobile parts that comply with CUSMA and to helping farmers who need potash for fertilizer. An explanatory statement issued by the White House says there would be no tariffs on goods from Canada and Mexico that claim and qualify for CUSMA preference.
*   **March 10:** Ontario Premier Doug Ford announces the immediate application of a 25 per cent surcharge on electricity exports to the U.S. as part of the province’s retaliation to Trump’s tariffs. Trump responds aggressively, saying he will double the rate on steel and aluminum tariffs set to be implemented March 12 to 50 per cent. He says on Truth Social that the move is in response to Ontario placing a 25 per cent surcharge on electricity it exports to the U.S. However, Ford agrees to suspend the province’s export tax later the same day.
*   **March 12:** The 25 per cent tariffs on steel and aluminum tariffs from all countries take effect. Canada hits the U.S. with a second tranche of retaliatory tariffs, enacting 25 per cent tariffs on $29.8 billion in U.S. goods, targeting steel and aluminum as well as other products including computers, sports equipment and cast iron goods.

The first piece on Monday named Tesla Inc and Apple Inc as examples of how China’s vast market and manufacturing capabilities have made it an indispensable partner of US firms.

The article struck a conciliatory tone, calling for greater China-US cooperation despite their competition.

Beijing targeted US agricultural and energy goods in its retaliation against the 20% blanket tariffs imposed on Chinese products by Trump this year.

Chinese authorities also launched an antitrust investigation into Alphabet Inc’s Google and put US gene-sequencing company Illumina Inc on a so-called blacklist of entities.

China’s top diplomat on Tuesday denounced the broad tariffs the United States imposed over Beijing’s alleged role in America’s fentanyl crisis, calling for Trump to remove the levies in an interview with Russian state-run news service RIA Novosti.

title: Most goods from Canada and Mexico remain exempt as Trump levies new tariffs worldwide - (Published 11 hour(s), 31 minute(s) ago)
content: Canada and Mexico were notably absent from a long list of trading partners the president announced he would tariff on Wednesday.
resumen:
President Donald Trump signed a series of executive actions Wednesday that slap tariffs on virtually all of its trading partners.
Canada and Mexico have avoided the sweeping 25% tariff many expected.
Trump announced new tariffs on nations from Cambodia to Serbia.
The “reciprocal” tariffs are meant to tariff countries that have existing tariffs for goods from the U.S.
Canada and Mexico will continue to see no tariffs on goods that comply with the USMCA trade agreement between the three countries.
Goods that don’t comply with the trade agreement will continue to be tariffed at the 25% rate Trump put in place last month.
Trump has been threatening a 25% across-the-board tariff on all goods from Canada and Mexico since late last year, unless the two countries do more to crack down on the flow of drugs across the border.
The tariff, which Trump signed an executive action to implement shortly after taking office, has now been delayed for months.
A tariff on cars built outside the U.S. would go into effect this week.

Wendy Cutler, a former U.S. trade negotiator, said Asian countries in particular have been hard hit.

Exiger calculated that the burden from the tariffs could fall heaviest on Chinese exports, which would face $149 billion in additional surcharges, while Vietnamese goods would face $63 billion, Taiwanese products $37 billion and Japanese goods $36 billion.

Prime Minister Anthony Albanese of Australia said the United States imposing 10 percent tariffs on the country had “no basis in logic.”

Luis de la Calle, a top Mexican trade economist, said it was good news for Mexico and Canada that they would not be subject to new tariffs beyond those previously announced.

Kurt Tong, a former senior U.S. diplomat and managing partner at The Asia Group, said these countries face a real dilemma.

title: India sees opportunity, as well as risk, in Trump’s trade war - (Published 21 hour(s), 34 minute(s) ago)
content: Although that is manageable for Mr Modi in the short term, it comes as the economy is slowing and the stockmarket slumping. A long trade war could undermine his goal of boosting India’s exports to ...
resumen:
India faces a watershed moment. On April 2nd, Mr. Trump unveiled “reciprocal” tariffs on America’s trade partners, including a 27% levy on Indian goods. Indian officials suggest India can weather any short-term pain and quickly agree to a trade deal with America that would unleash growth. Privately many worry that any deal would face fierce resistance at home. A drawn-out trade war could jeopardize the ambitious economic and political agenda of the prime minister, Narendra Modi.

India had tried to appease Mr. Trump by reducing tariffs on goods including bourbon and motorbikes before Mr. Modi visited Washington in February. The two leaders agreed to complete the first part of a trade deal by this autumn and to try to expand bilateral goods and services trade to $500bn by 2030 (from $210bn in 2024). They also agreed that India would buy more American oil, gas and arms to help cut its big bilateral trade surplus.

Piyush Goyal, India’s commerce minister, visited Washington in March and offered to cut more tariffs. India widened its offer to cover some 55% of American exports to India. It also scrapped a 6% tax on digital advertisements. Two telecoms operators, Reliance Jio and Bharti Airtel, struck deals to bring Elon Musk’s Starlink satellite-internet service to India.

India’s commerce ministry said on March 29th that the two sides had reached “an understanding on the next steps”. The apparent aim is to reach a goods-trade deal as early as August, with one on services to follow.

The new tariffs’ direct impact on India’s economy will be limited. Bilateral goods trade with America is around 3% of India’s GDP. Ajay Srivastava, a former Indian trade official who heads the Global Trade Research Initiative, suggests India could benefit from the higher tariffs on several other Asian countries, noting that pharmaceuticals, a big Indian export to America, were exempted.

America is India’s largest export market and the tariffs could strain individual sectors that are big employers, such as agriculture. The worst-affected sectors are likely to include seafood, as well as gems and jewellery, says Mr. Srivastava. The tariffs could also hit India’s exports of electronics, including locally assembled iPhones and other smartphones. India’s main share indices opened lower on April 3rd, with technology stocks hit hardest, while pharmaceuticals rallied.

Economists reckon that the tariffs, which were higher than expected, could cut India’s growth by around 0.8 percentage points.

A long trade war could undermine his goal of boosting India’s exports to $2trn by 2030 from $778bn in 2023-24 and accelerating annual GDP growth to at least 8%.

Since he took power in 2014 India has increased tariffs as part of his campaign to develop domestic manufacturing. It has also offered production-linked incentives (PLIs), rewarding companies that lift output over a baseline, to attract foreign manufacturers. Quality-control orders, non-tariff barriers that supposedly impose safety standards on imports, have proliferated too.

Domestic manufacturing languishes at 14% of GDP, down from 16% in 2015. Private investment has stagnated and foreign direct investment has gone into reverse. Reuters, a news agency, reported on March 24th that the PLI scheme would be allowed to lapse. Mr. Goyal recently warned Indian exporters to shed their “protectionist mindset”. Having walked away from a big regional trade deal in 2019, India is now negotiating deals with the EU and Britain as well.

Mr. Trump may push India to open government procurement to American firms and remove restrictions on data flows—demands India has long resisted.

title: The ‘Bazooka’ Europe Could Use to Fight Trump’s Tariffs - (Published 17 hour(s), 42 minute(s) ago)
content: European officials are weighing deploying a tool called the anti-coercion instrument that would potentially target American tech and financial giants.
resumen:
En la creciente guerra comercial con Estados Unidos, los funcionarios europeos están discutiendo la imposición de barreras a las importaciones de servicios estadounidenses con un arma comercial que podría permitir al bloque restringir a las grandes empresas tecnológicas y a Wall Street.

Ursula von der Leyen, presidenta de la Comisión Europea, dijo esta semana: "Tenemos el poder de contraatacar".

El presidente Trump ya ha anunciado aranceles sobre el aluminio, el acero, los automóviles y las autopartes, medidas que podrían perjudicar seriamente la inestable economía del bloque. Bruselas ha respondido anunciando que reimpondría gravámenes a las importaciones estadounidenses como las motocicletas Harley-Davidson, el whisky y otros bienes, algunos de los cuales fueron objeto de ataques durante el enfrentamiento transatlántico que el Sr. Trump instigó en su primer mandato.

Para contrarrestar los últimos aranceles recíprocos del Sr. Trump, los funcionarios europeos están considerando desplegar una herramienta política llamada instrumento anti-coerción, al que algunos se refieren como una "bazuca". El instrumento, que se adoptó en 2023 para responder a China pero nunca se utilizó, se considera una opción de último recurso si las conversaciones con la administración Trump van mal.

Bruselas podría adaptar la herramienta para atacar a los gigantes tecnológicos y las instituciones financieras de Estados Unidos. Un plan externo que ha estado circulando en las últimas semanas incluye una opción nuclear: limitar el acceso de los bancos estadounidenses al enorme mercado de contratación pública de la Unión Europea, lo que significaría cortar parcialmente a los bancos de proyectos por valor de aproximadamente 2 billones de euros (2,2 billones de dólares) cada año.

Otra idea en el plan preliminar es atacar las enormes sumas que los europeos invierten anualmente en empresas estadounidenses, un flujo anual de aproximadamente 300.000 millones de euros que se ha convertido en un punto de irritación para los funcionarios de la UE. Y finalmente, el plan preliminar dice que Bruselas "también podría aumentar la presión fiscal y regulatoria sobre las plataformas digitales estadounidenses".

El plan no aclaró el alcance, y mucho menos cómo se podría implementar alguna de las dos propuestas. Pero mostró cuán ampliamente están pensando los asesores políticos mientras el bloque sopesa su enfoque.

"Personalmente, creo que la gran bazuca debería usarse en primer lugar como elemento disuasorio", dijo Fabrizio Pagani, socio del banco de inversión Vitale y ex alto funcionario económico del gobierno italiano, refiriéndose a la herramienta anti-coerción. "Así que pónganla sobre la mesa y negociemos".

Olof Gill, portavoz de la Comisión Europea, dijo que el instrumento anti-coerción se estaba considerando mientras Bruselas traza su estrategia de negociación. Un punto es que, aunque la Unión Europea ha acumulado un gran superávit comercial en bienes, al mismo tiempo ha acumulado un déficit comercial de aproximadamente 110.000 millones de euros en servicios con Estados Unidos. Explotar ese punto podría ser clave en las negociaciones, dicen los asesores.

Pero algunos analistas y economistas temen que una negociación tan dura pueda ser contraproducente.

"Los aranceles sobre los servicios, al igual que los aranceles sobre los bienes, afectan directamente a los consumidores y a las empresas", dijo Joachim Klement, jefe de estrategia del banco de inversión Panmure Liberum, y agregó que sería una forma segura de escalar la guerra comercial.

"Simplemente estás echando leña al fuego de la estanflación", agregó.

title: Here's how Trump's 'half-baked tariffs' could impact the Kentucky bourbon industry - (Published 13 hour(s), 55 minute(s) ago)
content: In Trump's "Liberation Day" speech, he announced blanket 10% tariffs and additional country specific tariffs. Here's how it could impact KY bourbon ...
resumen:
President Trump announced a new round of tariffs on Wednesday, including a baseline 10% tariff on goods from most countries and additional tariffs on specific countries.

The tariffs are intended to boost American manufacturing and create jobs, but economists warn they could lead to higher prices for consumers.

The bourbon industry, a major part of the Kentucky economy, could be caught in the crossfire if other countries retaliate with tariffs on American whiskey.

Industry advocates are calling for a return to zero-for-zero tariffs on spirits, arguing that this would benefit American distillers, farmers, and the wider hospitality industry.

President Donald Trump announced his tariff plan on Wednesday, a day he dubbed "Liberation Day," that, across the board, includes a baseline tariff of 10% on essentially all other countries.

Additionally, Trump brought out a poster during the event in the White House Rose Garden to showcase specific tariffs on a variety of countries including: 34% tariff on China, 20% on the European Union, 46% on Vietnam, 32% on Taiwan, and 24% on Japan, among roughly a dozen other country specific tariffs.

As previously promised, Trump also levied a 25% tariff on foreign made automobiles, which will go into effect at midnight.

While alcohol products were not explicitly named as being tariffed, the blanket baseline tariff and country specific tariffs are likely to hit alcohol products made in foreign countries — which could prompt retaliatory tariffs that target American made products such as Kentucky bourbon.

U.S. Rep. Morgan McGarvey, D-Ky., told the Courier Journal: "I want to bring more manufacturing jobs home, but tariffs don't solve problems on their own. To work, they must be backed by a comprehensive plan...Donald Trump has not paired his overly broad, half-baked tariffs with any comprehensive strategy to return manufacturing jobs to the United States, and without one, these tariffs will only hurt working families and small businesses, while decimating Kentucky’s bourbon industry."

The tariffs, which Trump and political allies see as a key component in the "Make America Wealthy Again" movement, will be a "reciprocal tariff" program with the president stating, "they do it to us, we do it to them."

The tariffs were enacted through an Executive Order signed by Trump.

Trump said: "Today we are standing up for the American worker and we are finally putting America first."

Trump has repeatedly stated the goal of his tariff policy is to increase American manufacturing and encourage the onshoring and reshoring of industries to create more jobs for American workers.

Trump said: "Jobs and factories will come roaring back into our country."

The president believes the tariffs will "supercharge" the domestic industrial economy, "open foreign markets and break down foreign trade barriers," all of which he said will ultimately lead to "lower prices for consumers."

St. Louis Federal Reserve Bank President and CEO Alberto Musalem, who oversees the region which includes Louisville and much of Kentucky, previously said businesses along the supply chain, ranging from raw materials to manufactured goods, will most likely pass the higher prices on to consumers when tariffs hit.

Bourbon, one of Kentucky's signature products, has been an easy target for retaliatory tariffs in the trade war waged by Trump.

With the announcement of baseline and country specific tariffs that are intended to hit products from foreign countries, retaliatory tariff could be placed on alcohol from the U.S., including American whiskey, the family to which bourbon belongs.

Chris Swonger, president of the Distilled Spirits Council of the United States, DISCUS, said in a statement Wednesday: "We recognize that President Trump is working to secure fair and reciprocal trade and stand ready to work with the administration to untangle the spirits industry from the recent trade disputes so we can resume zero-for-zero trade with our major trading partners."

American spirits are a driving force of the U.S. hospitality industry economy, and intimately in Kentucky where bourbon is a $9 billion industry that crosses tourism, economic development and the restaurant industry.

Kentucky Democratic Party Chair Colmon Elridge said in a statement: "With these tariffs, President Trump is gambling with the lives of hard-working Kentuckians who are still waiting for him to fulfill his promise of lowering the cost of living 'on day one,'...Instead, he is doubling down on demands that have handcuffed our signature bourbon industry and jeopardized billions of dollars in trade with Kentucky’s top export markets, like Canada."

The U.S. spirits sector supports more than 1.7 million jobs.

Swonger previously told the Courier Journal that tariffs stand to harm these American workers and cause job losses from the farmers who grow the grains to the coopers who make the barrels to restaurant workers and more.

Swonger said: "We urge President Trump to liberate the U.S. spirits sector from these tariff disputes by negotiating deals that get us back to fair and reciprocal zero-for-zero tariffs for spirits products."

In 2018 during Trump's first presidency, tariffs he levied on steel and aluminum led to bourbon getting caught up in a trade war and facing retaliatory tariffs from the European Union. In the immediate aftermath while these EU tariffs were in place, American whiskey saw a decrease in exports.

Under President Joe Biden, a pause was negotiated on these tariffs, allowing for the American whiskey industry to start rebounding.

Swonger said: "The U.S. spirits sector has been the model of success for fair and reciprocal trade for decades. During the time that we had zero-for-zero tariffs with 51 countries, our industry flourished, benefitting U.S. distillers, farmers and the wider hospitality industry...A return to zero-for-zero tariffs with our key trading partners will enable the 3,100 distillers across the United States to partake in the limitless growth opportunities that exporting has to offer."

title: Trump announces sweeping new tariffs to promote US manufacturing, risking inflation and trade wars - (Published 7 hour(s), 14 minute(s) ago)
content: President Donald Trump declared on Wednesday a 10% baseline tax on imports from all countries and higher tariff rates on dozens of nations that run trade surpluses with the United States, threatening ...
resumen:
President Donald Trump announced on Wednesday a 10% baseline tax on imports from all countries and higher tariff rates on dozens of nations that run trade surpluses with the United States.

Trump said the United States would charge a 34% tax on imports from China, a 20% tax on imports from the European Union, 25% on South Korea, 24% on Japan and 32% on Taiwan.

Trump declared a national economic emergency to launch the tariffs, expected to produce hundreds of billions in annual revenues.

Trump imposed “reciprocal” tariffs on trade partners, acting without Congress through the 1977 International Emergency Powers Act.

The president’s higher rates would hit foreign entities that sell more goods to the United States than they buy, meaning the tariffs could stay in place for some time as the administration expects other nations to lower their tariffs and other barriers to trade that it says have led to a $1.2 trillion trade imbalance last year.

The tariffs follow similar recent announcements of 25% taxes on auto imports; levies against China, Canada and Mexico; and expanded trade penalties on steel and aluminum.

Trump has also imposed tariffs on countries that import oil from Venezuela and he plans separate import taxes on pharmaceutical drugs, lumber, copper and computer chips.

Senior administration officials said the taxes would raise hundreds of billions of dollars annually in revenues.

The White House could not say whether the tariff exemptions on imports worth $800 or less would remain in place.

Heather Boushey, a member of the Biden White House’s Council of Economic Advisers, noted that the less aggressive tariffs Trump imposed during his first term failed to stir the manufacturing renaissance he promised voters.

Rep. Suzan DelBene, D-Wash., said the tariffs are “part of the chaos and dysfunction” being generated across the Trump administration.

House Speaker Mike Johnson, R-La. said the tariffs could disrupt an economy with an otherwise healthy 4.1 % unemployment rate.

Canada has imposed some countermeasures in response to the 25% tariffs that Trump tied to the trafficking of fentanyl.

The European Union, in response to the steel and aluminum tariffs, put taxes on 26 billion euros’ worth ($28 billion) of U.S. goods.

European Commission President Ursula von der Leyen said that the EU has a strong plan to retaliate and will use it if necessary.

Italy’s premier, Giorgia Meloni, reiterated her call to avoid an EU-US trade war.

Ray Sparnaay, general manager of JE Fixture & Tool, a Canadian tool and die business, said the uncertainty has crushed his company’s ability to make plans.

The Brazilian government on Tuesday welcomed its Senate's push to advance the Reciprocity Bill, which would authorize tariff countermeasures against the United States. The Brazilian Vice-President Geraldo Alckmin applauded the Senate's effort to provide a legal framework for trade defense. The Brazilian Senate's Economic Affairs Committee approved the bill earlier on Tuesday with 16 votes in favor and none against. The legislation would allow Brazil to apply reciprocal tariffs and environmental standards in response to foreign trade restrictions. In response to additional US tariffs on automobiles, Japanese Prime Minister Shigeru Ishiba pledged on Tuesday to provide financing and procurement support to domestic companies. Ishiba said if the US implements a 25 percent tariff on car imports, the government will set up designated consultation offices in about 1,000 locations across Japan to meet the funding needs of affected companies. Ishiba said, "Japan is the largest investor in the US".

title: Trump’s trade war: What are reciprocal and secondary tariffs and how they defy WTO rules - (Published Apr 2, 2025)
content: Trump’s reciprocal tariffs aim to match foreign levies, with the "Dirty 15" nations facing the greatest impact due to their trade surplus with the U.S.
resumen: Donald Trump is set to introduce an import tax initiative called "Liberation Day," which aims to impose equivalent duties on nations that levy tariffs on American goods. This policy, known as reciprocal tariffs, will impose tariffs on imports equivalent to those levied on American exports by other countries, applied on a product-by-product basis. The goal is to promote fair trade and protect domestic industries. If a country puts a 10% tax on American-made automobile parts, the U.S. will impose the same amount of tax on that country's automobile parts. The White House may opt for country-specific tariff rates based on trade imbalances. Economists caution that these tariffs could drive up consumer prices and fuel inflation, particularly on imports from China, Canada, and Mexico. S&P Global Ratings estimates a potential one-time rise of up to 0.7% in U.S. consumer prices. Nations like India, South Korea, and Thailand are among the most vulnerable. A maximal approach could add up to 28 percentage points to average US tariff rates, creating a hit of 4% to US GDP and lifting prices by close to 2.5% over a two-to-three-year period. Trump has also signaled secondary tariffs on imports from nations purchasing Russian oil if Moscow fails to reach a ceasefire agreement. These tariffs would target countries like China, India, Turkey, and certain EU nations. Secondary tariffs penalize foreign entities that trade with a sanctioned nation. The WTO is a 166-member Geneva-based multilateral body that formulates rules for global trade and adjudicates disputes between countries. Under Article II of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT) 1994, WTO member countries cannot impose tariffs exceeding their bound commitments. America has refused to comply with the WTO ruling, arguing that it has the sovereign right to determine its national security policies. It has also blocked the WTO Appellate Body, preventing an appeal resolution.

title: Cities in states won by Trump would be most hurt by Canadian tariffs, analysis finds: Milwaukee is #10 - (Published 15 hour(s), 8 minute(s) ago)
content: A study by the Canadian Chamber of Commerce found 1,595 companies in the Milwaukee metro area export to Canada.
resumen:
A new analysis released last week by the Canadian Chamber of Commerce detailed the areas most dependent on exports to Canada, with San Antonio and Detroit topping the list of 41 U.S. metro areas. The findings show that the United States’ 25% tariffs on Canada and Canada’s retaliations could inflict meaningful damage in key states for U.S. politics.

Nearly half of what San Antonio exports, with its aerospace, auto and energy sectors, goes to Canada. About 40% of what the auto-driven Detroit area exports also goes to Canada. Trump’s wins in Michigan, Pennsylvania and Wisconsin were crucial for his overall victory in November’s presidential election — and Milwaukee and Pittsburgh also rank in the top 10 for exposure to a trade war with Canada.

The Milwaukee metropolitan area ranked #10. The Chamber found exports to Canada represent $2.1 billion of the $9.4 billion worth of goods exported and 2% of the metro’s entire gross domestic product (GDP).

The U.S. International Trade Administration says 2,812 companies in the Milwaukee metro area export their products to other countries, and 1,595 of them export to North American trade partners.

The analysis was conducted before the Republican president announced March 26 that he was placing additional 25% tariffs on imported autos and parts starting on April 3.

April 3 is also when a slate of additional, but unknown tariffs are expected to be announced, what Trump has dubbed “Liberation Day.”

Trump has placed 25% tariffs on many goods from Mexico and Canada, with a lower 10% tax on energy products and potash from Canada. Some of those tariffs have been suspended or delayed, though they’re set to fully hit in April.

Canadian leaders have warned that the United States would suffer in the form of higher prices, fewer jobs and slower growth because of the trade war. But an analysis by the Brookings Institution found that the economic pain would be more severe in Mexico and Canada because those countries are more reliant on the United States in terms of trade.

Trump’s stated reason for the tariffs is to stop illegal immigration and drug smuggling, though he’s also said that he dislikes the trade deficit with both countries and has taunted Canada by suggesting that it could become the 51st U.S. state.
